Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Development of Hierarchical Social Organization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fundamental goal of this research is to better understand the processes and mechanisms by which small scale traditional societies merged into larger social units and developed hierarchical social organization. The investigators believe that religious ritual and shared beliefs can play a role in this process as throughout history religious rituals have been documented occurring alongside such development. This research has current day relevance given the importance of religion as both an integrative and divisive force as evidenced in much of the developing world.
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Neill Wallis and Dr. John Krigbaum will investigate the development, spread, and impact of extensive religious rituals among Florida populations ca. A.D. 200 to 600 using a variety of analytical tools and archival research. The mortuary practices of this Middle Woodland period, referred to as "Weeden Island", show widespread and conspicuous uniformity that is characteristic of a religious movement. The proliferation of these practices was apparently coincident with increasingly integrated social networks and emergent high status for some individuals. Given these associations, the project examines the role of Weeden Island rituality in the initiation of emergent social inequality through investigation of human diet, mobility, social interaction, and community formation. In the context of conspicuous religious parity, this research endeavors to identify exactly how disparate communities interacted with one another, how integrated they were, and how these trends inflected social and political histories in the region.
Drawing on collections and archived field notes from 13 Middle Woodland mound sites distributed across peninsular Florida and curated at the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLMNH), this research will integrate (1) multiple lines of isotopic analysis of skeletal populations to generate data pertaining to diet and mobility, (2) osteological analysis to collect basic demographic and life history information on individual interments, (3) geochemical and petrographic analysis on Weeden Island mortuary wares to determine their ultimate provenance, and (4) technofunctional analysis to outline form and function of vessels and the potential for craft specialization. In addition, the uniformity of Weeden Island ritual practices will be evaluated through investigation of archived notes. These data and the correlation of variables will reveal specific historical trends in the practice and spread of Weeden Island rituality and its sociopolitical implications.
The broader impacts of the study include contributions to archaeological method and social theory, the training of students, and public outreach and education. In terms of method, the analytical protocol builds on established techniques and combines them in innovative ways. These data lend a rare multidimensional robustness to the investigation of the complex region-wide phenomenon of Weeden Island, permitting more nuanced and potentially transformative understandings of the movement and life histories of Middle Woodland people and objects. At a theoretical level, through its focus on mobility and intergroup interactions, the project redirects the search for causes of social inequality toward a historical investigation of the process of community formation at regional scales, and has anthropological implications for explaining the intersections of religion, identity, and political conflict.
The project provides advanced training and research experience for at least two Ph.D. students and several undergraduate museum and laboratory interns, and will form the basis for Ph.D. dissertations, and M.A. and honors theses. Results will be disseminated broadly and showcased through an Explore Research exhibit at the FLMNH and a companion website. In addition to scientific publications, archived data will be made freely available online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to better understand the processes and mechanisms by which small scale traditional societies merged into larger social units and developed hierarchical social organization. Religious rituals and shared beliefs are expected to have played a role in this process. For example, in many areas of the world such institutions develop to meet a range of new social demands pertaining to the routinization and scheduling of labor, the organization of larger co-residential groups, and coordination and maintenance of expanding networks of exchange. This research has current day relevance given the importance of religion as both an integrative and divisive force as evidenced in much of the developing world.

This research investigated the development, spread, and impact of extensive religious rituals among Florida populations ca. A.D. 200 to 1000 using a variety of analytical tools and archival research. The ritual practices associated with burial mound sites of this Middle and Late Woodland period, referred to as "Weeden Island," show widespread and conspicuous uniformity that is characteristic of a religious movement. The proliferation of these practices was apparently coincident with increasingly integrated social networks and emergent high status for some individuals. Given these associations, the project examined the role of Weeden Island rituality in the initiation of emergent social inequality through investigation of human diet, mobility, social interaction, and community formation.

Drawing on collections and archived field notes from 13 Woodland mound sites distributed across peninsular Florida and curated at the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLMNH), this research integrated isotopic data pertaining to diet and mobility, osteological analysis relevant to demographic and life history information, geochemical and petrographic analysis of Weeden Island pottery to determine provenance, technological analysis to understand pottery vessel form and function, and AMS dating.

AMS dating results from this, and other, projects indicate that the Weeden Island religious tradition most likely originated sometime during the late sixth century CE at Kolomoki in southwestern Georgia, the preeminent civic-ceremonial center with the largest resident population. Sourcing data show that ornate pottery made at Kolomoki or within the surrounding area is common at burial mounds up to 600 km distant, averaging nearly 20 percent of analyzed assemblages on the peninsular Florida Gulf coast. Nonlocal vessels with other manufacturing origins are significantly less common and not as widespread. Masterful local production of burial mound vessels is apparent at all sites, revealing a network of itinerant potters connected primarily by way of Kolomoki, perhaps as part of a ritual sodality.

Isotopic results both within and between sites analyzed support local ecological and geographic conditions, as predicted for pre-Columbian foragers engaged in local food procurement. Diets inferred from light stable isotopes of carbon and nitrogen support ‘broad spectrum’ C3-based diet with terrestrial plants and animals coupled to varying degrees with maritime food resources. Radiogenic isotope ratios, such as strontium, complement light isotope results and help to clarify life history context of individuals interred at these sites. 

Multiple lines of evidence contradict the initial expectation that regional religious integration is associated with emergent social status. AMS assays from mound contexts show that variability in mode of burial and accoutrements corresponds with diachronic changes across centuries and millennia rather than differences in status among individuals subsumed under the Weeden Island mortuary program. No significant differences in health or diet were observed within burial mound populations, except in occasional cases of nonlocal individuals that spent their formative years in distant communities, and these immigrants predate the spread of Weeden Island religious practices. Religious integration in this case is associated with elaborate processing, intermingling and homogenizing of bones that are limited to those of local individuals. While individual status is obscured, this trend is consistent with emergent hierarchies in which ranked corporate groups are invested in managing relationships with ancestors as an important basis for power.  

The project provided advanced laboratory training and research experience for numerous students, and was the basis for three undergraduate honors theses, three M.A. theses, and four Ph.D. dissertations. Isotopic, chemical and petrographic data provide important baselines for future work in the region and results are being disseminated through publically available online databases and web image galleries.
